DOCNAME: CASE OF WYNEN AND CENTRE HOSPITALIER INTERRÉGIONAL EDITH-CAVELL v. BELGIUM
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 6-1 as regards the inadmissibility of statement of grounds of appeal;No violation of Art. 6-1 as regards notification to the applicants of the hearing in the Court of Cassation;No violation of Art. 6-1 as regards the possibility of replying to the advocate-general's submissions;No violation of Art. 6-1 as regards refusal of the request for a reference for a preliminary ruling;Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed;Non-pecuniary damage - finding of violation sufficient;Costs and expenses partial award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . The first applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE . The second applicant has its registered office in GPE .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE a magnetic - resonance imaging ( MRI or ORG ) unit with a built - in electronic calculator DATE a high - technology medical device – was installed at the IMEC . In accordance with a royal decree of CARDINAL DATE , a department in which an MRI unit was installed was regarded as a “ high - cost medico - technical service ” within the meaning of LAW CARDINAL of LAW , consolidated on DATE . Pursuant to that statutory provision , such services had to be approved . The criteria for approval were laid down in the royal decree . The relevant department at the ORG had not , however , obtained the necessary approval .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Ministers of Public Health for the GPE - Capital bilingual region lodged a complaint with the public prosecutor against the first applicant for installing high - cost medical equipment without the prior approval of the minister responsible for public health . In DATE the first applicant and the ORG , his employer , which was civilly liable for his acts , were summoned to appear in ORG . ORG subsequently applied to join the proceedings as a civil party .
CARDINAL . NORP On DATE ORG acquitted the first applicant and cleared the ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE that judgment prompted the following speech by a member of ORG during the passage of a bill amending LAW :

“ I was shocked by the court ruling DATE in the PERSON case . Everyone knows Dr PERSON ’s habit of not caring about legislation . He illegally installs high - cost scanners at his hospital , the Edith - Cavell , and justifies his actions with arguments about medical ethics . ” ( summary record , ORG , DATE ordinary session , sitting of DATE )
CARDINAL . State Counsel ’s Office and the civil party appealed against the judgment of CARDINAL DATE .

In their appeal submissions the applicants argued , among other things , that the royal decree of DATE , which had formed the basis for the prosecution , was unlawful , particularly as it concerned a matter dealt with by legislation at community rather than federal level . They pointed out in that connection :

“ Section CARDINAL of the Hospitals Act empowers the King to lay down approval and planning criteria for the installation of magnetic - resonance imaging ( MRI ) units with built - in electronic calculators , with a view to controlling public expenditure .
The decree lays down a number of conditions relating to :

( CARDINAL ) the department in which the equipment is installed ; ( CARDINAL ) the number of employees and their qualifications ; ( CARDINAL ) the safety of the equipment and of the surrounding area ; ( CARDINAL ) quality control of the work carried out by users ; ( CARDINAL ) the geographical location of the equipment ( the requirements vary according to the power of the equipment ) ; and ( CARDINAL ) the number of beds .

At best , only the fifth criterion can possibly come under the responsibility of ORG . The other conditions pursue a quite different aim , namely that of regulating the provision of health care , responsibility for which currently falls to the Communities by virtue of section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(I)(CARDINAL ) of GPE DATE on institutional reform .

Seeing that CARDINAL of the CARDINAL conditions it lays down do not come under the responsibility of the national authorities , the royal decree of DATE should be declared unlawful in its entirety since it can not be applied only in part . ”

The applicants also submitted that the complaint , civil - party application and appeal by ORG were unlawful , inadmissible and void ; that the complaint by ORG infringed the principle of equality enshrined in LAW and CARDINAL of the LAW in that the public authorities , without applying any objective or reasonable criteria proportionate to the aim pursued , had refrained from reporting other similar offences to the public prosecutor ; that the royal decree of DATE and , at the very least , the penalty for which it provided , had been tacitly repealed ; and , lastly , that the decree infringed several fundamental rights , including the right to life and health , freedom of choice with regard to medical treatment and the prohibition of inhuman and degrading treatment .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG reversed the judgment , imposed a suspended fine of MONEY on the first applicant and ordered him to pay costs , applying , inter alia , sections DATE and CARDINAL of LAW . The ORG was held to be jointly and severally liable for payment of the fine and the costs . In particular , ORG dismissed the applicants’ arguments that the royal decree of CARDINAL DATE had been tacitly repealed or was unlawful .

CARDINAL . The applicants appealed to ORG against that judgment . In their pleadings they relied on , inter alia , Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the LAW , their main arguments being that ORG had based its judgment on contradictory and inconsistent reasoning and had , in particular , applied section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW ( which concerned high - cost medical “ equipment ” ) , whereas , pursuant to the royal decree of CARDINAL DATE , an MRI unit constituted a high - cost medico - technical “ service ” , the setting up or operation of which came under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of that LAW ; that ORG had omitted to examine whether the royal decree of CARDINAL DATE was compatible with LAW DATE on institutional reform , which had apportioned powers among the ORG , the ORG and the Regions , or with the principle of equality enshrined in LAW and CARDINAL of the LAW , and that it had failed to refer the matter to GPE and Procedure Court ; that it had infringed the general principle of the burden of proof and the presumption of innocence ; that the lawfulness of the royal decree of CARDINAL DATE , which ORG had applied , had not been established ; and that , in any event , the penalty for which it provided had been tacitly abolished by a subsequent provision , namely section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the PERSON of DATE .

Under the second limb of their second ground of appeal , the applicants asserted that ORG had breached section CARDINAL ) of GPE and Procedure Court ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) by refusing to refer a preliminary question to that court as to whether section CARDINAL of LAW contravened the rules laid down by or pursuant to the LAW to determine the respective powers of the ( federal ) ORG , the ORG and the Regions . They submitted in that connection :

“ The appellant argued in his appeal submissions that the royal decree of DATE did not comply with LAW DATE on institutional reform in that it laid down approval criteria relating to health - care policy , a matter which is the responsibility of the ORG .

The judgment appealed against should not merely have assessed whether the royal decree of DATE was compatible with the consolidated Hospitals Act which it implemented , since the King is not entitled to stay or dispense with the enforcement of the laws on institutional reform ; moreover , the consolidated Hospitals Act does not confer , and could not possibly have conferred , on him the authority to derogate from the laws on the distribution of powers . ...

Furthermore , seeing that [ ORG ] held that the royal decree complied with the consolidated LAW , it was required by section DATE ) of GPE DATE to submit a preliminary question to GPE and Procedure Court as to whether the LAW contravened the rules on the distribution of powers between the ORG , the ORG and the Regions . ”
The applicants accordingly asked ORG to submit the following question to ORG :

“ In so far as section DATE of the consolidated Hospitals Act of CARDINAL DATE is to be construed as empowering the King to lay down the rules set out in the royal decree of CARDINAL DATE ‘ establishing standards which a service that has installed a magnetic - resonance imaging unit with a built - in electronic calculator must satisfy in order to be approved as a high - cost medical service within the meaning of LAW , consolidated on DATE CARDINAL’ , does that provision contravene :

( CARDINAL ) the rules on the distribution of powers , seeing that by virtue of , inter alia , section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(I)(CARDINAL ) , policy on the provision of health care within and outside health institutions is the responsibility of the FAC ; ... ”

Under the third limb of the second ground of appeal , based on LAW , which lays down the obligation to give reasons for judgments and decisions , the applicants asked ORG to submit a further preliminary question to ORG as to whether section CARDINAL of LAW breached Articles DATE , which safeguarded the principle of equality and non - discrimination .
CARDINAL . The civil party , which was the respondent before ORG , filed pleadings in reply on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants filed supplementary pleadings in which , among other things , they set out CARDINAL fresh grounds of appeal – based , in their submission , on public policy – alleging violations of various provisions of the LAW and the LAW , in particular LAW and CARDINAL . In their new grounds they submitted that the royal decree of CARDINAL DATE was unlawful ; that the principle of equality had been infringed in that , among the many hospitals that possessed the equipment in issue , only the applicants had been prosecuted ; that the penalty set forth in LAW had been abolished ; and , lastly , that a number of fundamental rights , including the right to life , had been infringed . The applicants also reiterated their request to have the preliminary question cited above submitted to ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE the date set for the hearing was entered on the list displayed at the registry and in the courtroom of ORG .

CARDINAL . ORG held a public hearing on DATE . The applicants assert that they were not notified of the date of the hearing , such an omission being in accordance with LAW , second paragraph , of LAW ( ORG ) , which provided that dates set for hearings in ORG were entered on the list of pending cases DATE in advance , without any further notification . As is apparent from the record of the hearing , the court heard evidence from the reporting judge , the representative of ORG and counsel for the civil party . ORG did not attend the deliberations that took place after the hearing . On DATE , after the deliberations , ORG dismissed the ORG appeal , having declared their supplementary pleadings inadmissible as being out of time , pursuant to LAW paragraph , of the ORG , which provided that persons appealing to ORG could not file any pleadings once DATE had elapsed from the date on which the case was entered on the general list .

CARDINAL . NORP In its judgment , delivered on DATE , ORG held , in particular , that the reasoning given in the judgment appealed against had not been contradictory and that the contention that ORG had applied section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) instead of section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW amounted to complaining of an incorrect reference to the applicable legal provision , an error that had no bearing on the penalty imposed since the CARDINAL provisions in question provided for the same penalty . It further held that the complaint that the royal decree was incompatible with LAW of DATE amounted to challenging the PERSON ’s constitutionality , a question outside ORG jurisdiction . Furthermore , ORG was under no obligation to submit a preliminary question to GPE and Procedure Court if it considered that the reply to the question was not essential for it to be able to give judgment .

ORG further noted that ORG had not infringed the rules on the burden of proof as , in dismissing the complaints that the royal decree of CARDINAL DATE was unlawful , it had based its decision not on the appellants’ arguments but on the consideration that it was not for the courts to take the place of the executive in assessing the appropriateness of a measure falling within the executive ’s sphere of competence .

ORG also dismissed the argument that the royal decree in question was unlawful or had been repealed , holding that section CARDINAL of the Law of DATE was in no way incompatible with LAW of DATE as it merely provided for an additional sanction in the form of a limit on fees and , consequently , had not tacitly abolished the criminal penalties provided for in that Act .

Lastly , ORG refused the request to submit a preliminary question to ORG . In so far as the question concerned the compatibility of section CARDINAL of LAW with the rules on the distribution of powers , ORG held :

“ Furthermore , in so far as the appellant asked the ORG to submit a preliminary question to ORG as to whether section CARDINAL of LAW , consolidated on DATE , contravenes the ‘ rules on the distribution of powers , seeing that by virtue of section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(I)(CARDINAL ) , policy on the provision of health care within and outside health institutions is the responsibility of the PERSON , he did not state the precise nature of the alleged contravention .

Under the aforementioned section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(I)(CARDINAL ) of LAW of DATE on institutional reform , policy on the provision of health care is a ‘ person - related matter’ falling within the responsibility of the Communities [ matière personnalisable ] , but only subject to certain exceptions , such as legislation laying down organisational principles , or funding arrangements , where these are governed by such legislation .

Since the consolidated LAW DATE lays down organisational principles governing hospitals and , in particular , their funding , the appellant should have explained in the preliminary question he intended to have submitted to ORG precisely why he considered that section CARDINAL of the Act was not covered by the exceptions whereby legislation laying down organisational principles , and the funding arrangements made in such legislation , are not ‘ person - related ORG for which responsibility is assigned to the Communities by LAW former LAW bis ) of the LAW , but are matters which under LAW remain the preserve of federal legislation .
Accordingly , the request for the submission of a preliminary question in relation to this limb of the ground of appeal is inadmissible as being insufficiently precise . ... ”

ORG also declared the preliminary question inadmissible in so far as it concerned the compatibility of section CARDINAL of the Act with Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the LAW , on the ground that the question was “ extraneous both to LAW , the only provision alleged to have been infringed in this limb of the ground of appeal , and to the failure to reply to the appellant ’s submissions , the only complaint raised in the limb in question ” .
CARDINAL . At the material time Article CARDINAL bis of the ORG provided :
“ Appellants wishing to make oral submissions in ORG shall set out their grounds of appeal in pleadings which must be communicated in advance to ORG DATE before the hearing .

However , they may not produce any pleadings or documents – other than those concerning the discontinuance or resumption of the proceedings or indicating that the appeal has become devoid of purpose DATE have elapsed from the date on which the case was entered on the general list . ... ”
CARDINAL . At the material time LAW ORG provided :
“ Proceedings shall be governed by the provisions of Articles CARDINAL to DATE of the Judicial Code .

Nevertheless , by way of derogation to the second paragraph of Article PERSON of the LAW , the date set for a hearing shall , without any further notification , be entered on the list of cases pending before the court DATE prior to the hearing .
The list shall be displayed at the registry and in the courtroom and shall contain the names of the parties , the lawyers and the representative of ORG instructed to make submissions in the case . ”

In practice , however , the parties and their lawyers were entitled to ascertain the date of the hearing by telephoning the registry of ORG or requesting it by ordinary mail to inform them of the date in writing . That practice was long established and its existence was reiterated in ORG DATE report for DATE .

However , the PERSON of DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) repealed the second and third paragraphs of LAW ORG , bringing the arrangements for notifying the parties of hearings in criminal cases into line with those laid down in the second paragraph of Article PERSON of the Judicial Code .
CARDINAL . At the material time LAW provided :

“ After the report has been read out , submissions shall be heard from the lawyers present at the hearing . Their addresses shall relate exclusively to the issues of law raised in the grounds of appeal or to objections to the admissibility of the appeal .
ORG Office shall then make its submissions , after which no further documents shall be accepted . ”

However , since ORG ( judgment of DATE , Series A no . CARDINAL-B ) , ORG had allowed the parties or their lawyers to address the court a second time after ORG had made his submissions . The parties could also seek an adjournment in order to give themselves additional time to prepare their submissions in reply , which could , moreover , take the form of a memorandum for the deliberations ( note en délibéré ) . Such requests were systematically allowed by ORG . In the rare cases in which ORG submissions had been prepared in writing and communicated to the court before the hearing , a copy was also sent to the parties before the hearing . ORG took note of those judicially initiated procedural amendments in its Interim Resolution DH ( CARDINAL ) CARDINAL of DATE .
CARDINAL . In a letter of CARDINAL DATE to the Minister of ORG , ORG at ORG made the following observations in relation to the present case :

“ In the instant case the submissions were made orally and the parties did not reply to them , either orally or by submitting a memorandum for the deliberations , as they were entitled to do , if necessary after an adjournment which they would have been granted in accordance with standard practice if they had requested it . By establishing this practice in a statutory instrument , the PERSON of DATE confirmed that the practice complied with the requirements of NORP case - law . ”
CARDINAL . A law of DATE , which came into force on DATE , amended LAW as follows :

“ After the report has been read out , ORG Office shall make its submissions . Submissions shall then be heard from the parties . Their addresses shall relate exclusively to the issues of law raised in the grounds of appeal or to objections to the admissibility of the appeal or of particular grounds .

Where the submissions of ORG are in writing , the parties may , at the very latest during the hearing and solely in reply to those submissions , submit a memorandum in which they may not raise any new grounds of appeal .

At the hearing each party may seek an adjournment in order to reply orally or by means of a memorandum to the written or oral submissions of ORG . The ORG shall fix the time - limit for submitting the memorandum . ”
CARDINAL . Other relevant provisions of the Judicial Code read as follows :

“ The rules set out in this Code shall apply to all proceedings , except such as are governed by statutory provisions which have not been expressly repealed or by principles of law whose application is not compatible with that of the provisions of this Code . ”
“ The file shall include the following :
CARDINAL . State Counsel ’s opinion ;
A list of documents , kept up to date by the registrar and indicating the date on which the documents were submitted , shall be appended to the file . ”
“ In so far as no derogation is laid down in the provisions of this Book , the rules concerning first - instance procedure shall be applicable to appeal proceedings . ”
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of GPE of DATE on GPE and Procedure Court , as worded at the material time , provided :
“ ( CARDINAL ) The Administrative Jurisdiction and Procedure Court shall give a preliminary ruling , in the form of a judgment , on questions concerning

( i ) contravention by CARDINAL of the statutes , decrees or rules contemplated by LAW rules laid down by or pursuant to LAW to determine the respective powers of the State , the Communities and the Regions ;

( ii ) without prejudice to ( i ) above , any conflict between decrees or rules as contemplated by LAW promulgated by different legislative authorities , provided that the conflict stems from the scope of the decrees or rules in question ; and
( iii ) contravention of Articles CARDINAL , CARDINAL and DATE of the LAW by one of the statutes , decrees or rules contemplated by LAW .
( CARDINAL ) A court before which a preliminary question has been raised must seek a ruling on the matter from GPE and Procedure Court .

However , the court shall be exempted from this obligation where the action is inadmissible for procedural reasons based on rules which are not themselves the subject of an application for a preliminary ruling .

A court whose decisions are open to challenge in the form of an ordinary appeal , a petition to reopen proceedings , an appeal on points of law or an application for judicial review in the ORG d’Etat shall also be exempted from this obligation
( i ) where GPE and Procedure Court has already given a ruling on a question or appeal having the same object ;
( ii ) where it considers that the reply to the preliminary question is not essential for it to be able to give judgment ; or
( iii ) where it is manifestly apparent that the law , decree or rule contemplated in LAW does not contravene any rule or LAW contemplated in section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) . ”
